What you don‚Äôt know, unless you see it for yourself, is that at her shrines, in all her homes, Amaterasu has a mirror. The mirror is kept at a specific height. 

The height is such that, whenever you kneel, you will see yourself there. 

You are the one who brings the light back.

Now, this is usually the end of the story. The girl leaves her king (for a while). The girl gives birth (to a movement). The girl outruns the wolf (for now). The girl quits the cave for beauty and laughter and fun. 

But there‚Äôs a part of the story you don‚Äôt know.

The others pounced, and held the stone fast, and showed her their shiny new friend: the woman in the mirror. 

And she remembered she was beautiful, and nothing Susanou or anyone did could ruin that, that everything about him was temporary, even pain.

And so the light returned.

Amaterasu rolled back the stone 

(because there are other Solstice stories, like the one about a scared girl in a dark and lowly place who grew a boy from nothing, and how he was murdered by the state, how she somehow lived after watching that happen)

‚Ä¶and poked her head out.

But it was Uzume, the funny one,  the sassy friend, the goddess of all arts, who had the best idea. The gods wanted a party, but she WAS the party. So she upended a washtub, and started to dance, and then to stomp, and then to strip. 

The crowd lost it.

And even gods get FOMO.

But Omohikane hatched a plan. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll put on a show!‚Äù they said, because that is how you save something. You get everyone together and remind them beauty exists. 

Ishikoridome made a mirror. Tamano‚Äôoya made a necklace. Koyame divined where she was. Tajikaro stood at the cave.

Things fell apart. This happens when the one who always shows up stops showing up. The order of things was disrupted. The whole world was a storm. The other gods were annoyed. It was just a horse. Not even a special one. Couldn‚Äôt she just get over it and get back to work?

(Because this is what happens, sometimes: sometimes the things you see follow you wherever you go, no matter how small and strong your hiding place is. And for her, it was that poor, innocent horse. Which was all innocent creatures. And also innocence itself.)

Some accused her of taking her blazing ball and going home. Others agreed she needed a break, boundaries, time. 

But she was so terrified at his wickedness that she could not move. Neither could time. There was no moving on, only dark and cold and silence where once was life.

The sun hid in a cave. 

(You might know another story, about Spring and her king, and the Lady with the lantern who helped her Mother find her. This is different.)

She hid in shock at his violence. She hid in shame at not having stopped him. She despaired, and the world froze.

And then, one day, he broke her spirit.

He could not stand beauty, or friendship, or loyalty, or grace, or talent, or intelligence, or anything else which he did not possess.
